titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the George E. Vincent Papers FA030

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-12-16 00:20:35 -0500.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: George E. Vincent was born in Rockford, Illinois, in March 1864. He attended Yale University and received an A.B. in 1885. He received a Ph.D. from the University of Chicago in 1896.

In 1886, Mr. Vincent became the literary editor of the Chautauqua Press. From 1888-1889, he was Vice-President of the Chautauqua Schools. He became Principal in 1898 and was President of the Chautauqua Institution from 1907-1915. Mr. Vincent was a teaching fellow in sociology at the University of Chicago and in 1904 became a full professor. From 1900-1907, he was Dean of the Junior College and from 1907-1911 he served as Dean of Arts, Literature and Sciences. From 1911-1917, he was the President of the University of Chicago.

In 1917, Mr. Vincent became the President of the Rockefeller Foundation and served in that capacity until 1929. He was also a trustee of the Peiping Union Medical College from 1917-1929 and of the China Medical Board, Inc. from 1930-1938. He was a member of the General Education Board from 1914-1929.

Mr. Vincent took part in a variety of activities. He was a member of the United States Delegation to the Pan American Conference in Santiago, Chile, in 1923, a member of the President's Public Works Commission in 1931, a lecturer at the Scandinavian University in 1933, Chairman of the Hospital Survey Committee of the United Hospital Fund of New York City in 1935, a President of the American Sociological Society and a member of the American Scandinavian Foundation, the commission for Relief in Belgium and the Educational Foundation.
Together with A. W. Small, Mr. Vincent published "An Introduction to the Study of Society" in 1895. In 1896 he published "Social Mind and Education."

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use." If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the user's responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The George E. Vincent collection covers the period from 1929-1945. Material includes some correspondence and a family bulletin commenting on the rise of Nazi Germany. The major portion of the collection consists of testimonials to the career of Mr. Vincent. Among the correspondents are George E. Vincent and A. C. Krey.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The papers of George E. Vincent were deposited with the Rockefeller Foundation Archives in April 1967 by Gladys Russell.
